questions.text: Preterm labour is defined as when the labour starts before _____
questions.solution:
Preterm labour is defined as when labour starts before 37 completed weeks (<259 days) counting from the first day of the last menstrual period.

Timing of delivery Terminology
<33 weeks Early preterm
34 to 36 weeks Late preterm
37 to 38 weeks Early term
39 to 40 weeks Full term

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Progesterone intake is not a risk factor for preterm labour. Progesterone is used for prophylaxis of preterm labour.

Risk factors for preterm labour:

  • Maternal history -
    • Previous history of spontaneous abortion or preterm delivery
    • Artificial reproductive technique
    • Asymptomatic bacteriuria or recurrent UTI
    • Smoking
    • Maternal stress
  • Pregnancy complications -
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Antepartum haemorrhage
    • PROM
    • Overdistended uterus - polyhydramnios, multiple pregnancy
    • Cervical incompetence
    • Uterine malformations
    • Intrauterine death
  • Maternal chronic diseases -
    • Hypertension
    • Nephritis
    • Diabetes
    • Severe anaemia
    • Periodontal diseases

Option A: Multifetal pregnancies are common following artificial reproductive techniques and can be associated with preterm labour.

Option B: Asymptomatic bacteriuria or bacterial vaginosis can cause spontaneous preterm labour.

Option C: Chronic diseases like periodontal disease increase the risk of preterm labour.

questions.text: Late preterm births include births between _____.
questions.solution:
Late preterm births include births between 34 to 36 weeks of gestational age.

Timing of delivery Terminology
<33 weeks Early preterm
34 to 36 weeks Late preterm
37 to 38 weeks Early term
39 to 40 weeks Full term

questions.text: A 31-year-old G3P2 woman presents at 29 weeks of gestation with a blood-tinged vaginal discharge. She is suspected to have preterm labour. Which of the following findings will not help confirm her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A cervical length of 32 mm (3 cm) does not help in confirming preterm labour as it is highly unlikely when the cervical length is >3 cm. The length of the cervix in preterm labour, as measured in transvaginal ultrasound is ≤2.5 cm.

Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation).

Features of preterm labor:

  • Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, with/without pain 
  • Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% 
  • TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm
  • Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge or bleeding PV

Predictors of preterm labor:

  • Clinical predictors:
    • History of prior preterm birth
    • Multiple pregnancies
    • Presence of genital tract infection
    • Symptoms of preterm labour
  • Biophysical predictors:
    • Uterine contractions ≥4/hour
    • Bishop score ≥4
    • Cervical length (TVS) ≤25 mm
  • Biochemical predictors:
    • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervical/vaginal discharge >50 ng/mL
    • Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alpha

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on TVS.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to predict preterm labour in a patient having irregular uterine contractions at 30 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
IL-2 is not a biochemical predictor of preterm labour.

Biochemical predictors of preterm labor:

  • Fetal fibronectin
  • IL 6
  • IL 8
  • TNFα

Investigations of preterm labour: 

  • Fetal fibronectin >50 ng/ml
  • TVS - length of cervix ≤2.5 cm
  • Urine culture
  • High vaginal swab
  • Maternal salivary estriol
  • Uterine activity monitoring

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1L0 woman came for a routine antenatal checkup at 20 weeks of gestation. She is worried about preterm labour as her previous baby was born preterm. What will be the timing and cut-off limit for fetal fibronectin (fFN) assay to predict this condition?
questions.solution:
Fetal fibronectin value of >50 ng/mL in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 and 34 weeks is predictive of preterm labor. 

Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua.  It is normally found in the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and after 37 weeks of gestation. 

It is measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. When the test is negative, it reassures that the delivery will not occur within the next 7 days.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with blood-tinged vaginal discharge at 35 weeks of gestation. A nitrazine paper test was performed on her. What is this test used to detect?

choices.text: Fetal blood cells in Rh isoimmunisation

questions.solution:
The nitrazine paper test is used to detect premature rupture of membranes.

The nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH >6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of 4.5 - 6.0.

False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, and bacterial infections.

The below image shows the nitrazine paper.

Option A: Fetal hemoglobin in vasa previa is detected by Apt test.

Option B: Estimation of the volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation in Rh isoimmunisation is done by Kleihauer-Betke test.

Option D: In abruptio placenta, the diagnosis is mainly based on clinical features.

questions.text: A sample of the vaginal fluid from the posterior fornix of a patient gave a positive nitrazine paper test. Which of the following conditions does not give a false positive result?
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios shows a false negative nitrazine paper test.

Nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH >6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of 4.5 - 6.0.

False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, and bacterial infections. False-negative nitrazine test can be seen in the case of scanty amniotic fluid.

questions.text: Transvaginal sonography in a case of clinically suspected preterm labour revealed a short cervix and funnelling of the internal os. What is the shape of the cervix that is likely to be seen here?
questions.solution:
U-shaped cervix is seen on tranvaginal sonography (TVS) in preterm labour.

On TVS, the cervix should be assessed to determine whether funnelling (internal os width >5 mm) is present.

Shape of cervix Inference
T shaped Normal
Y shaped Suspicion of preterm labour
V shaped Funneling of internal os
U shaped

Incompetent os

Preterm labour

The following is a TVS image showing a V-shaped cervix:

ACOG recommends a transvaginal ultrasound in pregnant females between 16-24 weeks of gestational age with a history of previous preterm labor for the measurement of cervical length.

questions.text: A multigravida presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes. According to RCOG guidelines, which of the following antibiotics is preferred for her?
questions.solution:
According to RCOG guidelines, erythromycin is the preferred antibiotic in the case of PPROM (preterm premature rupture of membranes).

Spontaneous rupture of membranes before the onset of labour between 28 to 37 weeks is called preterm premature rupture of membranes. 

If PPROM occurs between 28 to 34 weeks, prophylactic antibiotics and corticosteroids are given to the patient.

questions.text: A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation presents with labour pains but her membranes were intact. You decide to start her on corticosteroids and a tocolytic. Which of the following drugs will not be useful in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of preterm labour with intact membranes and progesterone is not used as a tocolytic in these cases.

Progesterone can be used for the prophylaxis of preterm labour in women with a previous history of spontaneous preterm labour.

Glucocorticoid therapy is given in preterm labour when the period of gestation is <34 weeks to hasten fetal lung maturity. Short term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). 

Tocolytics that can be given as short term therapy include:

  • Terbutaline
  • Magnesium sulphate
  • Indomethacin
  • Nifedipine
  • Atosiban

questions.text: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour. Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects.

According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestation but may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3 days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). 

Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects:

Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects

Beta-adrenergic agonists:

  • Ritodrine
  • Terbutaline
  • Isoxsuprine

Headache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, ARDS

Fetal heart failure, intrauterine death

Neonatal hypoglycemia, intraventricular haemorrhage

Calcium channel blockers:

  • Nifedipine
  • Nicardipine
  • Verapamil
 Hypotension, headache, flushing, nausea -

Oxytocin antagonists:

  • Atosiban

(not approved for use in India)

 Nausea, vomiting, chest pain -
Magnesium sulphate Flushing, perspiration, headache, muscle weakness, respiratory paralysis Neonatal cardiac arrest, lethargy, hypotonia, respiratory depression

COX inhibitors:

  • Indomethacin
  • Sulindac
 Heartburn, asthma, GI bleeding, thrombocytopenia, renal injury, platelet dysfunction, oligohydramnios Constriction of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension, intrauterine growth restriction

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for tocolysis in a patient with preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Placenta previa is not a contraindication for tocolysis. In placenta previa, nifedipine and magnesium sulphate are used as tocolytics.

Contraindications to tocolysis:

  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Preeclampsia/Eclampsia
  • Advanced labour
  • Fetal distress
  • Intra-uterine death
  • Congenital anomalies not compatible with life
  • Pregnancy >34 weeks
  • Abruptio placenta

questions.text: A G3P1A1 woman presents with preterm labour at 27 weeks of gestation. She tells you that her previous child who was born preterm developed cerebral palsy. Which of the following drugs can you use to reduce the incidence of this condition?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulphate has a neuroprotective effect and hence decreases the risk of developing cerebral palsy.

Magnesium sulphate can be used for neuroprotection in preterm labour when the pregnancy is <32 weeks. The dose is 4 g IV over 20 mins followed by an infusion of 1 g/hr.

questions.text: A primigravida was administered tocolytics and corticosteroids for preterm labour. The following day, she suddenly started coughing and gasping for air. On examination, her BP was 160/100 mmHg and SpO2 was 80% in room air. Which of the following drugs could have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pulmonary edema which is a side effect of the tocolytic ritodrine.

Acute pulmonary edema in pregnancy can be due to:

  • Non-cardiogenic causes -
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Acute haemorrhage
    • Sepsis
    • Tocolysis with ritodrine and magnesium sulphate
    • Vigorous IV fluid therapy
  • Cardiogenic causes

Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects:

Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects

Beta-adrenergic agonists:

  • Ritodrine
  • Terbutaline
  • Isoxsuprine

Headache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, ARDS

Fetal heart failure, intrauterine death

Neonatal hypoglycemia, intraventricular haemorrhage

Calcium channel blockers:

  • Nifedipine
  • Nicardipine
  • Verapamil
 Hypotension, headache, flushing, nausea -

Oxytocin antagonists:

  • Atosiban

(not approved for use in India)

 Nausea, vomiting, chest pain -
Magnesium sulphate Flushing, perspiration, headache, muscle weakness, respiratory paralysis Neonatal cardiac arrest, lethargy, hypotonia, respiratory depression

COX inhibitors:

  • Indomethacin
  • Sulindac
 Heartburn, asthma, GI bleeding, thrombocytopenia, renal injury, platelet dysfunction, oligohydramnios Constriction of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension, intrauterine growth retardation

questions.text: Which of the following tocolytics can cause multiple fractures in the fetus if given for a prolonged duration?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulphate can cause multiple fractures and hypocalcemia in a preterm baby.

The FDA warned against prolonged use of magnesium sulphate to arrest preterm labour. The antagonistic effect of magnesium lowers the calcium levels in the fetus. This causes bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed to the drug for more than 5 to 7 days.

questions.text: Post-term pregnancy refers to pregnancy continuing beyond ______.
questions.solution:
ACOG defines post-term pregnancy as a pregnancy continuing beyond 42 completed weeks of gestation.

For clinical purposes, a pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery (> 294 days) is called a post-term pregnancy.

Inaccurate LMP is the most common cause of misdiagnosis of post-term pregnancy. Hence, early ultrasound dating is important to determine fetal gestational age.

questions.text: A woman presented for an antenatal checkup 2 weeks past her EDD. Which of the following is not an etiological factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
Maternal stress is associated with preterm labour, not post-term pregnancy.

Etiological factors of post-term pregnancy are:

  • Inaccurate LMP
  • Heredity
  • Primiparity
  • Previous prolonged pregnancy
  • Sedentary habits
  • Elderly multipara
  • Anencephaly
  • Placental sulphatase deficiency

questions.text: You have performed an artificial rupture of membranes in a primigravida for augmentation of labour. You note the amniotic fluid to be saffron-coloured. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Saffron-coloured amniotic fluid is seen in postmaturity.

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text: A newborn baby was found to have wrinkled, patchy skin, a long thin body and long nails. Which of the following could be a cause for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of postmaturity syndrome which can occur due to placental sulphatase deficiency.

Etiology of post-term pregnancy:

  • Wrong dates - inaccurate LMP (most common)
  • Heredity
  • Previous prolonged pregnancy
  • Anencephaly
  • Placental sulphatase deficiency (leads to decreased estrogen synthesis)
  • Primipara/ elderly multipara

Features of postmaturity syndrome in a newborn:

  • Wrinkled, patchy, peeling skin, particularly prominent on the palms and soles
  • Long, thin body suggesting wasting
  • Long nails
  • Eyes open and unusually alert
  • Looks old and worried

Note: Placental aromatase deficiency causes disorder of sexual development of fetus.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman came for a routine ANC at 41 weeks of gestation. On examination, her Bishop score was 2. She was admitted for fetal monitoring and induction. Which of the following complications would you not anticipate in the fetus even if her pregnancy continues further?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pregnancy continuing further would cross 42 weeks of gestation and thus turn into a post-term pregnancy. Hypoglycemia is seen in a post-term neonate.

Complications of post-term pregnancy:

  • During labour:
    • Fetal hypoxia
    • Labour dysfunction
    • Macrosomia
    • Shoulder dystocia
    • Oligohydramnios
    • Cord compression
    • Birth trauma 
    • Meconium aspiration
    • Intracranial haemorrhage
  • Following birth:
    • Meconium aspiration syndrome
    • Hypoxia
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Polycythemia
    • Neonatal convulsions

questions.text: A primigravida was admitted at 42 weeks for induction of labour. Which of the following conditions is she not at an increased risk for?
questions.solution:
The risk of post-partum haemorrhage does not increase in post-term pregnancy.

Complications of post-term pregnancy are due to placental insufficiency and placental ageing. It manifests as placental infarcts and calcifications. During post-term pregnancy, diminished placental function can cause oligohydramnios. 

Complications of post-term pregnancy are:

  • During labour:
    • Fetal hypoxia
    • Labour dysfunction
    • Macrosomia
    • Shoulder dystocia
    • Oligohydramnios
    • Cord compression
    • Birth trauma 
    • Meconium aspiration
  • Following birth:
    • Chemical pneumonitis, atelectasis, pulmonary hypertension (due to meconium aspiration)
    • Hypoxia
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Polycythemia
    • Neonatal convulsions

questions.text: The term small for gestational age implies birth weight ______
questions.solution:
Small for gestational age implies birthweight is <10th percentile for gestational age.

With respect to the size, a newborn can be appropriate, small or large for gestational age.

Birth weight Terminology
<10th percentile Small for gestational age
>90th percentile Large for gestational age
Between 10th and 90th percentile Appropriate for gestational age

questions.text: What is the normal pH of amniotic fluid?
questions.solution:
The normal pH of the amniotic fluid is 7.1 - 7.3

The normal pH of the vaginal secretions is 4.5 - 5.5. In premature rupture of membranes (PROM), the pH of the vaginal secretions becomes 6 - 6.2 as the amniotic fluid mixes with it. This forms the basis for nitrazine paper test.
